description.plain:
System of a Down, also known by the acronym ‘SOAD’ and often shortened to ‘System,’ are an Armenian four-piece rock band from Southern California, formed in 1994.




The band achieved commercial success with the release of five studio albums, and Toxicity, Mezmerize and Hypnotize have all debuted at number one on the Billboard 200. System of a Down has been nominated for four Grammy Awards, and their song “B.Y.O.B.” won the Best Hard Rock Performance of 2006.



(Toxicity’s album art)

The group briefly disbanded in August 2006 and reunited in November 2010, embarking on a tour for the following three years. They had two subsequent worldwide tours in 2015 and 2017.

System of a Down has sold over 40 million records worldwide, and two of their singles, “Aerials” and “Hypnotize,” reached number one on Billboard’s Alternative Songs chart.




The band currently consists of four Armenian Americans:

Serj Tankian: lead vocals, keyboards, guitar on occasion.
Daron Malakian: vocals, guitar.
Shavo Odadjian: bass, backing vocals.
John Dolmayan: drums.



(SOAD’s actual formation)

description.plain:
Rick Rubin, who produced Toxicity for System of a Down, cites this song as one of his most important projects. He told Rolling Stone:

This song was originally going to be called “Self-Righteous Suicide,” and the record company rebelled. …I remember wanting to go to the mat and keep the title, and the band decided, “Let’s call it ‘Chop Suey!’” which I thought was kind of funny.

Chop-suey is the Americanization of the Chinese quick dish tsap sui, which means “odds and ends, mixed bits” in the Cantonese dialect. The song title is a play on “Self-right-Chop Suey-cide,” that has a further sort of humor in that they mixed up a controversial word into a nonsensical word to create a more ‘radio-friendly’ title.

The song enjoyed success, climbing the charts after its August 2001 release before virtually disappearing from airways after 9/11. The song’s chorus, with its congratulatory “self-righteous suicide,” and lament, “I cry when angels deserve to die” was considered a bit too raw for listeners at the time. In the wake of the tragedy, Clear Channel Communications (now iHeartMedia) put out a memo to its subsidiary radio stations  temporarily blackballing (but not outright banning) it, along with 164 other “lyrically questionable” songs. Eventually, the record resurfaced on the charts—in part due to its earlier popularity, in part due to the lack of new singles released that September. However, it remains one of System of a Down’s worst performing US singles, particularly relative to the song’s global performance.

Although the lyrics are viewed as confrontational, the singer is actually challenging the listener to “wake up” and reconsider the way that they judge and deride people who are engaged in self-destructive behaviors. The song culminates in a biblical connection to Jesus before his death on the cross, with the singer ostensibly having chosen his “self-righteous suicide” so that these ‘sinners’ would be forgiven.

description.plain: “Toxicity” is one of System of a Down’s biggest hits, the song reached No. 70 on Billboard Hot 100 and No. 3 on Mainstream Rock chart. During a performance at the 2005 Download Festival, Daron Malakian said that the song was about Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), a learning disorder that causes a person to have trouble concentrating, etc. The video for the song was directed by the band’s bassist Shavo Odadjian, just like “Aerials” video.

description.plain:
“B.Y.O.B.” (“Bring Your Own Bombs”) is the first single released from American heavy metal band System of a Down’s fourth album Mezmerize.

Like their earlier song “Boom!,” it was written in protest against the Iraq War.

B.Y.O.B. means “Bring Your Own Bombs,” as opposed to the common interpretation “Bring Your Own Booze,” referring to the Iraq War as one big party for the United States, where instead of Jägerbombs they drop real ones.

It made onto numerous “Top 40” playlists around the globe, including Germany, New Zealand, Australia and the United States, and occasionally made it to #1 on other music shows.

description.plain:
“Aerials” was released in June, 2002 as the third single from System of a Down’s second album Toxicity, which itself was released in September, 2001.  It was critically and commercially successful; the song was nominated for Best Hard Rock Performance at the 2003 Grammy Awards.



The overall theme of the song is our mistaken views of ourselves as being individual and isolated from the rest – mankind and other lifeforms – and how we actually are a tiny part of something greater, from which we come when we are born, and to which we go when we die. It speaks of clinging to life and not accepting death, ‘cause we see death as an ending, not as another step of existence. When we die, our matter is decomposed and is transferred to things like worms that feed on us, to the atmosphere in the form of gas, and to the ground and plants that feed on him. We are always moving through the circle of existence, there is no stillness, only movement and transformation.

On many CD issues, “Aerials” is listed as a single track with a length of 6:11. In reality, “Aerials” itself ends at around 3:54, while the rest of the length is taken up by a hidden track unofficially named “Arto.”

description.plain:
Sugar is an American obsession. It is in all of our food and we have basically become addicted to it.

The term ‘sugar’ is also a well-known euphemism for cocaine, which has even worse addictive effects than sugar itself.

description.plain: “Hypnotize” is the eponymous debut single of System of a Down’s fifth album. The song talks about how governments manipulate (or “hypnotize”) people, essentially placating them and keeping them focused on propaganda so they can maintain control over the people over whom they rule.

description.plain:
“Lonely Day” is a song by System of a Down, from Hypnotize. Contrary to popular belief, this song is not about Daron Malakian’s brother, because he is an only child. He wrote this song and provides lead vocals on it. This song has a heavy guitar solo at the end, with a dreary theme throughout.

The song appeared in Disturbia, a 2007 movie starring Shia LeBeouf which was about a kid who stays on house arrest and watches his neighbors to pass the time. The song appeared in a sequence in the movie where Shia’s character tries to find ways of keeping himself from dying of boredom.

description.plain: “Prison Song” is a criticism of the prison-industrial complex, the war on drugs, and the incredibly high rate of incarceration in America compared to other modern nations. The track opens SOAD’s best-selling album, Toxicity, reflection the main structure on most of the album’s songs: a mixture of melody and screaming, metal and pop, Serj Tankian and Daron Malakian.

description.plain: Seems to be a grim illustration of how Hollywood takes normal people looking to fulfill dreams of being an actor/actress, and then viciously changing them into fake people. Some may say actors live a double life, acting one way in movies, another in public, and even another in their personal lives. Fame can do tragic things to people. Jim Morrison, Kurt Cobain, and Janis Joplin are icons, living legends that died before their time. Others fame completely destroys.

description.plain: The fifth track and second single of System of a Down’s 1998 self-titled debut album. It speaks of June, a girl going through a procedure to insert a v-chip in her brain, controlling her thoughts and dreams. It metaphorically speaks of the control imposed on our will by the government, the media and the system. “Spiders” is a fan favorite track for its haunting atmosphere and powerful vocal performance of Serj Tankian.

Some parts of the song are just Serj Tankian talking about how is to be in a manifestation and how the authority treats you. A deer dance
Invitation to peace
War starring you in the face

Some parts of the song are just Serj Tankian talking about how is to be in a manifestation and how the authority treats you. In others, he talks about the importance of the protests to change your local community or maybe the world, like it seems on the bridge:

A deer dance
Invitation to peace
War starring you in the face

description.plain:
“Question!” is the second single off of SOAD’s fourth album Mezmerize. The song alternates between five different time signatures – 5/4, 9/8, 6/4, ¾, and 4/4 – giving a wildly irregular, yet melodic, rhythm.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ENBv2i88g6Y

The music video for the song features a boy and a girl portrayed in different stages of their lives, onstage as though in a play. In the end, the girl eats berries and dies and the boy grieves her death, before the cycle of life repeats. The concept for the video was proposed by bassist Shavo Odadjian.

The song could be interpreted as the pondering of the afterlife, or the possibilities of reincarnation. He is wondering if our life completely ends when we physically die, or if our spirit remains.

description.plain:
“Needles” is a song that talks about the danger of abusing drugs, more specifically heroin, comparing it to have a parasite in your body; the band advertises everybody, don’t do drugs—pull the tapeworm out of your ass!

The song has also more Daron Malakian’s vocal appearance, but is a little more melodic, as he said:

I wanted to add a bit more harmony for myself in the songs and that required tastefully mixing in some softer guitars between the really heavy parts.

description.plain:
“Radio/Video” is dedicated to the band members that left the band in the early years (when the band was named SOIL), because, according to them, “there’s no future in the band.” Now that System of a Down has a worldwide recognition, they show their ex-bandmembers how they persevered despite their lack of hope and support.

The music has a mixture of rock, metal and reggae. The song never reached any chart, although it’s one of the band’s most streamed songs.

description.plain: Besides environmental aspects, this song could be viewed as a dialogue between God and Jesus. The line “make the forest turn to wine” certainly alludes to this. When talking about System of a Down’s creativity, Rick Rubin used “Forest”’s guitar riff as an example. The track, unlike others, doesn’t have a great Daron Malakian participation on vocals.

description.plain:
“Bounce” is the seventh track on System of a Down’s second album Toxicity. Daron said in a concert that the song is about sex, but based on the lyrics, it could be about group sex (often referred as an “orgy”), the ‘pogo stick’ Serj talks about is basically a dick.

The song was used in the 2016 children’s film, The Secret Life of Pets.

“Jet Pilot” is one of those songs that nobody really knows the meaning behind—neither Serj Tankian, maybe. Following the band’s Armenian descendency, the song could talk about a, or a series of, Carpet Bombing attacks on Armenia, as

The skies right before
Right before they went grey

But, like many SOAD songs, nobody from the band explained the meaning of it, as their lyrics are ‘open to interpretation.’ Also, some fans speculate that the song talks about the Shelling of Stepanakert, a bombardment in Armenia.

description.plain:
Now this is how you start an album, especially one titled Steal This Album. It’s like a jab at modern-day consumerism, especially with a chorus that houses this message:

Need therapy, therapy, advertising causes need

The marketing mantra of “create a need” is blamed for Serj’s obsession with the contents of his fridge. Rather than drag us along for the ride, he lays the situation out and invites us to steal their album to shield us from contributing to this phenomenon.

“Chic ‘N’ Stu” is also a shortened way of saying “Chicken Stew.” It’s also paying homage to Chick Hearn and Stu Lantz, sports announcers, the former who coined the term “Ball game’s in the refrigerator.”

description.plain:
The opening track of SOAD’s first album is, in general, a criticism about pedophile cases in churches and extremely religious people, it isn’t criticizing people’s faith. Daron also talked about that in a interview:

I’ll be honest with you: politically, I have no issue with people, but my beef sometimes is with religion at the end of the day and that offends people, I guess, more than telling people what to do. But I just think a lot of people… Politicians use religion and they get their troops riled up with religion. And it’s not just here with Christianity, it's… Those dudes, like Bin Laden, these dudes are all politicians themselves they use the simple-minded and the poor and they promise them things and that’s how they rile up their troops using religion. And we don’t see that as the same as our politicians, but they play the same games with their people over there as the politicians play with the people over here to get them riled up, to go to war… ‘You’re fighting for freedom.’ I just think religion is something… It could be a beautiful thing for the individual, but when it becomes organized, that’s when religion starts taking a kind of ugly turn to me.

description.plain:
This song details the negative effects science has had upon our society. While it is more often than not hailed in a positive ‘omniscient’ light, Serj believes it has robbed us of the most powerful part of our existence.

Historically religion has been the primary source of education and ideologies, but as we have developed a greater understanding of scientific laws the focus of ‘knowledge’ has shifted from blind faith to concrete evidence.

Most historic disputes have involved or been centralised around religion, and it has been used historically to appease the masses living in impoverished conditions with promise of reward in the after life if we suffer in this one. We have replaced what has been our most powerful motivator with undeniable, uninterpreted facts.

The main point is that faith and spirit are more powerful than any laws of physics or amount of scientific facts, and that removing this crucial element from our existence will destroy all that we have known and stood for.

It’s not about knowing, its about believing.

description.plain:
“Sad Statue” talks mainly about the government, but it talks about war and history too. It is a anti-government song, like many other SOAD songs, like “B.Y.O.B.” or “F**k the System,” for example.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=705nFEpaxmI

The sad statue in this song is the Statue of Liberty, that is unhappy because people spend all time arguing with each other, and have mostly ignored the fact that the government can be taking away their rights. With no liberty, there’s no happiness.

description.plain:
“Mr. Jack” talks about living within a corrupt police state, where those in authority can arrest and condemn whoever they please. The song has calm verses, a melodic chorus, and a heavy outro, a band’s masterpiece.

System of a Down, in its first demo tape, released a version of this called “P.I.G.”

description.plain:
“X” (Multiply) is a song about immigration, overpopulation and, a topic that is touched on in many of SOAD’s songs, the Armenian Genocide of 1915. The movie screamers, which is about the Armenian Genocide, features band members like Serj Tankian and Daron Malakian.

This song was written prior to the self-titled album, System of a Down, but was held back until Toxicity so it can be worked upon. It was played live a few times between 1997–2001, however.

description.plain:
“She’s Like Heroin” makes a comparative of prostitution and drug addiction and, if you want to consider, talks about love too. The music is one of the poppiest songs on Hypnotize.

System of a Down as a band never played this live, but Malakian played in one solo live show:

description.plain: “Boom!” is anti-war and directly related to the declaration of war with Iraq. The video clip was directed by Michael Moore and shows footage of the largest protest in the world which took place on the 15th of February 2003 in more than 600 cities around the world.

description.plain: “Attack” starts off Hypnotize with a bang—some would argue the song attacks your ears. The track is sonically the polar opposite of its sister album, Mezmerize’s intro “Soldier Side.” Where Mezmerize ends somberly with the line, ‘You should have never trusted Hollywood,’ “Attack” startles you into the reality you’re faced with now that you’re in Hollywood.

description.plain:
If the title of the song wasn’t clue enough; this song is just a big fuck you to the system.

A lot of the band’s personal work goes toward preventing/spreading awareness of war and genocide. The United States (and other governments) have a big history of starting unnecessary conflicts so in SOAD’s eyes – they are part of the system they, and many others, try so hard to prevent. The song is all about taking the initiative and calling out the systems we’ve learned to accept.

description.plain:
All the members in System are of Armenian descent and outspoken about their views of the Armenian Genocide of 1915. This song is a giant middle finger to the Turkish government, as well as a hope that the genocide would be officially recognized by the American government. The title is meant to be an acronym for “Politically Lying, Unholy, Cowardly Killers.”

“Holy Mountains” is another SOAD song about the genocide.

description.plain: “Innervision” is a melodic but aggressive track in which Serj appears to look inward whilst searching for the answers to life and the universe. The bridge is indicative of a man restless for change, motivated to better himself, and convinced of his path, whether that be through religion or gaining an ironclad sense of self.

description.plain:
Man made shame

This line is the crux of the whole song. It states that humanity as a collective clings to the Ego, believing it to be as real as the source, to our own detriment. Individuals carry around this “Pain Body” of shame believing they have to move on and deal with it, but this is ironically the cause of their man made shame.

description.plain:
“A.D.D” is also a disease known as Attention Deficit Disorder, the American Dream Denial goes with this because the disorder causes absent-mindedness, difficulty focusing, forgetfulness, problem paying attention. Its indirectly saying that Americans are completely oblivious that the American dream no longer exist. Also a good amount of Americans have these symptoms of A.D.D.



It should be noted, however, that “A.D.D.” is no longer the proper terminology. It is “A.D.H.D.,” which is a disorder that has two primary presentations and is spectrum-like by nature. Because of this, it’s possible to have all or most of the symptoms of each presentation of A.D.H.D., which is classified as the combined presentation.

description.plain:
“U-Fig” is Hypnotize’s seventh track and it talks about mob mentality. People join rallys just to “belong” and be a part of something. Not all people of course, but many. Not just protests or anything like that but societal pressure to conform in general.
The song is meant to make people realize that they have their own mind and don’t have to conform to their group of friends, class, co-workers, protesters, etc. Basically:

Stop and think what you’re conforming to.

description.plain: The closing track of System of a Down’s 2001 album Toxicity, hidden at the end of the previous track Aerials. “Arto” is very different stylistically from the rest of the album, having a more traditional folk sound with Armenian chants than the heavier alternative metal sound in the rest of the album. It’s based on an Armenian church hymn called “Der Voghormya” (“Lord Have Mercy”) and features fellow Armenian musician Arto Tunçboyacıyan on the duduk.

description.plain: “Bubbles” uses a prolonged metaphor of life as a ‘bubble jungle’, which could mean a plethora of things, but the pairing of fish would suggest that it’s describing the ocean. The idea of a ‘jungle’ also shows that it may be hard to escape. This bubble jungle describes the cities and towns we live in where we represent the fish. We continue on in this environment, unaware of the dangers, but not determined to take the initiative and break the mold. Instead carrying on – like mindless fish.

description.plain:
“CUBErt” talks about how society is becoming dumber every day, everyone is cliche. How we blindly follow authority without question, we just sit back and watch our society crumble before us like we are in a movie theater. The music is very short and is rarely played live.

Q*bert is also an arcade game that was very popular, but repetitive and somewhat mindless.

description.plain:
“36” is named so because it is SOAD’S 36th track on their entire discography. Also, on the leaked version of Steal this Album! (called Toxicity II), this track was originally called “Your Own Pace.” The song actually goes all the way back to 1996, first being played live (as shown here) prior to appearing on a demo tape released before their self titled album.

The track also clocks in at 36 measures long.

description.plain: “Störagéd” seems to be a slightly abstract song about individuality in which the singer uses allusions to abortion.  The verses speak of growth, stagnation, and change. In the chorus, we are told to stand up for ourselves. “The spine align”, is to have backbone, or be strong and be true to yourself. The fetus is mine acts as a reminder that one can choose to be true to their essence.

description.plain: “Friik” is a demo that originally appeared on System of a Down’s fourth demo tape. The tape was never officially released to the public, having been recorded solely for the purpose of being sent to record labels to garner interest. The song is about the slow descent into madness and the question everyone has to ask themselves at least once in their life: “Am I crazy?”

description.plain: “Temper” is a rare demo off System of a Down’s second demo tape, which also features another rarity, “Honey,” and the demo version for “Soil.” It was written and performed prior to the self-titled debut even though it didn’t make the final cut. “Temper” was played for the first time since 1999 at the 2015 Rock in Rio Festival.

description.plain: “Honey” is a rare demo off System of a Down’s second demo tape, which also features another rarity, “Temper”, and the demo version for “Soil”. It was written and performed prior to the self-titled debut even though it didn’t make the final cut. SOAD have brought the song back on numerous occasions in later years.

description.plain:
Although never actually included on any of System’s albums, this “song” would commonly be played by the band as an intro to their shows. The lyrics are usually slightly varied from show to show.

This song was originally going to be a System song, but it was later scrapped and took into Daron Malakian and Scars on Broadway as their song “Enemy” in their 2008 album Scars on Broadway.

description.plain:
The album Toxicity II was leaked before Steal This Album! was released, leading to some changes. “Defy You” is the Toxicity II version of “Nüguns,” which made it into the 2002 album.

Some noticeable changes are the lyrics, only Serj singing in the choruses, and the first verse of Nüguns in the third verse.

description.plain:
“Flake” is the second track of the first SOAD’s demo tape and it has never been released in an official album by the band, not even encountered on the bootleg album Storaged Melodies.

In the comments to a mirror of the song on YouTube, the first drummer of System of a Down, Ontronik “Andy” Khachaturian, revealed that this song was recorded as a tail-end to the previous track, “P.I.G.” He also revealed that, despite the lyric during the chorus being often assumed to be “fuck you in your flake,” the lyric was actually “fuck you in your face.”

description.plain:
“Toast” is the third song on System of a Down’s untitled demo tape. The drummer for the first four demo tapes, Ontronik “Andy” Khachaturian, said that this song was originally called “Flake” in the comments of a YouTube mirror of this song. Aside from that, not much else is known about this song.

Due to the low audio quality and Serj’s distorted mic, the lyrics are nearly unintelligible.

description.plain: P.L.U.C.K. reveals the view of the members in System of a Down about the Armenian Genocide. The title is meant to be an acronym for “Politically Lying, Unholy, Cowardly Killers”. Unlike in the final version, this version is longer owing to the extended outro. The lyrics are changed a bit, too.

Unlike in the final version, this version is longer owing to the extended outro. The lyrics are changed a bit, too.

songs.lyrics:
[Intro: Serj Tankian]
Elimination, Elimination, Elimination
Die! Why?! Walk down! Walk down!

[Verse 1: Serj Tankian & Daron Malakian]
A whole race; Genocide
Taken away all of our pride
A whole race; Genocide
Taken away, watch Them all fall down!

[Bridge: Serj Tankian]
Don't speak, don't hear, don't everybody scream
100 thousand dying on your TV screen
Don't speak, don't hear, nothing real to fear
The sick man of Europe finishing his meal

[Verse 2: Serj Tankian & Daron Malakian]
Recognition, restoration, reparation
Recognition, restoration, reparation
Watch them all fall down!

[Pre-Chorus: Serj Tankian]
Revolution, the only solution
The armed response of an entire nation
Revolution, the only solution
We've taken all your shit, now it's time for restitution

[Chorus: Serj Tankian & (Daron Malakian)]
The plan was mastered and called Genocide
(Never want to see you around)
Took all the children and then we died
(Never want to see you around)
The few that remained were never found
(Never want to see you around)
All in a system of...

[Breakdown: Serj Tankian & (Daron Malakian)]
Down! Down! Down!
Down! Walk Down!
(Watch them all fall down)

[Verse 3: Serj Tankian]
They tried to terminate us
Knowing no one would fuss
It's time to take it over, it's time for the attack
They tried to terminate us
Knowing no one would fuss
It's time to take it over, it's time for the attack

[Chorus: Serj Tankian & (Daron Malakian)]
The plan was mastered and called Genocide
(Never want to see you around)
Took all the children and then we died
(Never want to see you around)
The few that remained were never found
(Never want to see you around)
All in a system of a down...

[Bridge: Serj Tankian]
Hangman, hangman...
Hangman, guilty, hangman, guilty
Hangman, hangman, guilty, guilty
Hangman, hangman, guilty, guilty
Hangman, hangman, guilty, guilty
Hangman, hangman, guilty, guilty
Hangman, hangman, guilty, guilty
Hangman, hangman, guilty, guilty

[Outro: Serj Tankian]
Fuck you like a dog when I see you barking like a dog
Fuck you like a dog when I see you barking like a dog
Fuck you like a dog when I see you barking like a dog
Fuck you like a dog when I see you barking like a dog

Cursed Earth!
Cursed Earth!
Cursed Earth!
Cursed Earth!

[Verse 1: Serj Tankian]
I will never feed off the evergreen luster of your heart
All because we all live in the valley of the walls
When they speak we can peek from the windows of their mouths
To see the land the women chant as they fly up to the sun

[Chorus: Serj Tankian]
You never think you know, why?! Know!
You never think you know, why?! Know!
You never think you know, why...?
Know! Know! Know!

[Verse 2: Serj Tankian]
Books all say different things while people flap their yellow wings
Trying to soar, being a whore, life and almost everything
The sheep that ran off from herd, maybe dead, but now's a bird
Able to fly, able to die, able to fuck your mother’s earth

[Chorus: Serj Tankian]
You never think you know, why?! Know!
You never think you know, why?! Know!
You never think you know, why...?
Know...

[Bridge: Serj Tankian]
On the other side...The other side... Other side...
Do you ever try to fly? Do you ever try to fly?
Have you ever wanted to die? Have you ever wanted to die?
Don't ever try to fly, don't ever try to fly
Don’t ever try to fly unless you leave your body on the other side!
Never try to die, did you ever try to die?

[Chorus: Serj Tankian]
Know! You never think you know, Why?!
Know! You never think you know, Why?!
Know! You never think you know, Why?!
Know! Ever think you know, why...?
Know!
